Now Mount Stewart Square is closely linked to its its development is closely linked to that the coal industry in South Wales
the mining of coal in the South Wales valleys in the
1790s onward meant that card developed into a port through which the coal was shipped and exported worldwide
It was initially transported using the Glenorchinshire Canal and later by rail on the Taft Vale Railway
Both of which terminated close to the site of the square a number of docks were constructed to
Filosylate the movement of this coal and the entire Bute town area of Cardiff was transformed to accommodate the new industry
and by the 1830s
Cardiff became the preeminent iron exporting port
shipping almost half of Britain's overseas iron exports between
1840 and
1870 and
then coal began to dominate and
the population of the area increased accordingly and
The grid pattern residential suburb for port related workers was built on land which included the site of the square
Now Mount Stewart Square was constructed in
1855 as a very select resident residential enclave around ornamental gardens
merchants and sea captains and originally consisted of 45 stuccoed three-story townhouses
The land was originally mud fat, but later the Cardiff glassworks had partly occupied the area as
A result the underlying soil was a mixture of mud and slag from the glass which
Which required 30 feet of concrete shafts to be constructed
That rested on a bed of hard gravel in order to construct the foundations of the square
In the period immediately before construction of the square commenced the land was used as a stables for canal horses
Named after Lord Mount Stewart the area was the vision of the second Marquis
John Crichton Stewart
Second Marquis of Bute who wanted to create a grand Georgian space to rival
Barclay Square in London
The development of the square was part of his vision to transform
Cardiff into a major port
improve the value of his own lands in Cardiff itself and increase the value of the royalties he could charge on his coal fields
As the docks rose in prominent wealthy residents moved out and it became a commercial centre
the construction of the coal exchange building
Solidified the change in focus to commercial and it became central to the coal trade activity
the coal exchange area meant that
Those of the original townhouses not converted were replaced by purpose-built offices for coal and shipping agents
The
Building surrounded the coal exchange housed coal companies banks and agents
most of
Cardiff's notable architects of the period are represented
including Alexander roots
architect of the Bute state Edwin Seward EWM Corbett Percy Thomas and Henry Budging
The impact of World War one was significant on the square
Having a damaging effect on the coal industry
By 1921 only six of the 52 companies operating in 1898 were still in business
with the industry never recovering
The coal exchange closed
Which in reduced which in turn reduced the demand for commercial premises on the square and allowed boarding houses to be established
And by the early early 20th century all banks had vacated their properties on the square
The western side of the square saw a gradual demolition of original properties and by the
1990s was no longer enclosed on its border with a canal much of the land was being used at open-air car parks
Until the construction of st. James and st. Stephen's mansions which once again enclosed the square
Mount Stewart Square has been home to a number of religious buildings in addition to its function as a
residential and commercial space the only remaining building st. Stephen's Church
